---In neat@yahoogroups.com, irvin <ihwang@m...> wrote:
> Hi,
>     I'm new to neat and I was trying to do some simple things like
add 
> an AND and OR case in addition to the XOR operation.  I am running
the 
> c++ implementation and the only thing I thought needed changing was
the 
> evaluation function more specifically how the errorsum was
calculated
> i.e.
> for "or"
>    
errorsum=(fabs(out[0])+fabs(1-out[1])+fabs(1-out[2])+fabs(1-out[3]));
> and for "and"
>    
errorsum=(fabs(out[0])+fabs(1-out[1])+fabs(1-out[2])+fabs(1-out[3]));
> 
> The problem is that when I run the program for OR and AND it rarely 
> finds a solution and if it does the final network seems overly
complex 
> and usually takes many more generations than XOR despite being a 
> "simpler" function.  My question is whether there should be more to 
> change in the program or if neat is just better with XOR than AND
or 
> OR(I don't see why that would be...).  I figured since they were
all 
> binary logic functions the parameters could stay the same and the 
> starting genome seemed as simple as it got so that didn't look like
a 
> problem.  I'm not too familiar with neat yet; maybe I'm overlooking 
> something simple so any tips would help.   Thanks.
> 
> irvin h.

Hi Irvin, actually NEAT is finding a solution, it just doesn't realize
it's found it because it thinks you are still doing XOR.  The way it
checks to see whether it's done in the XOR experiment is separate from
the fitness funcion.  Look at the lines:

   if ((out[0]<0.5)&&(out[1]>=0.5)&&(out[2]>=0.5)&&(out[3]<0.5)) {
    org->winner=true;
    return true;
  }
  else {
    org->winner=false;
    return false;
  }

These lines are the ones that check if you have a winner.  Note they
are not the same line where fitness is computed that you mention
above.  So you have to change *both*.  In other words, for example,
for OR it would be:

 if ((out[0]<0.5)&&(out[1]>=0.5)&&(out[2]>=0.5)&&(out[3]>=0.5)) {

After that "winner check" is fixed, it should work.  I notice NEAT
finding a solution almost immediately (i.e. reaching a fitness of 16)
on the OR test.

Let me know if you have any other questions.

ken
